div.head:
Additionis exempla
Examples of addition

p.s:
Additio
Addition

Si duo numeri sint similes plani; factus ex illis est quadratus,
cuius radix est medium proportionalis, inter datos.
If two numbers bcdd, bcff are similar planes, their product is a square whose root bcdf is the mean proportional between the given numbers.

Si similes plani dividantur per maximum communem divisor,
quoti sunt quadrati.
If similar plane numbers bcdd, bcff are divided by their greatest common divisor, the quotients are squares.

Si duo numeri sint similes solidi; factus e quadrato unius per alterum,
est cubus; cuius radix est una medium proportionalis, videlicet inter datos
et proxima ad illum numerum qui factus fuit quadratus.
If two numbers bcdfff, bcdggg are similar solids, the product of the square of one with the other is a cube, whose root bcdffg is one mean proportional beteen the two given numbers, and nearest to that number that was made a square.

Si similes solidi dividantur per maximum communem divisor,
quoti sunt cubi.
If similar solid numbers bcdfff, bcdggg are divided by their greatest common divisor, the quotients are cubes.

Si duo numeri sint similes planoplani; factus e cubo primi
per secundum est primum quadrato-quadratum cuius radix est primum
medium proportionalis, inter datos.
If two numbers are similar plano-planes bcdfgggg, bcdfhhhh, the product of the cube of the first with the second is a square-square, whose side bcdfgggh is the first mean proportional between the given numbers.

Si similes plano-plani dividantur per maximum communem divisor,
quoti sunt quadrato-quadrati.
If similar plano-plane numbers bcdfgggg, bcdfhhhh are divided by their greatest commmon divisor, the quotients are square-squares.

div.head:
b.8. Radicum extractio.
Extraction of roots

p.s:
1. 2. 3. significant
ordinem proportionalium
in diagramatis.
1, 2, 3, signify the order of the proportions in the diagram.

Ergo radix.
Therefore the root.
Blank page

Calculation of $ \sqrt{fg + bd} $.
This is an algebraic version of the problem posed in Euclid
X.59 , to find the square root (or side) of a sixth binome.
The same problem was also worked on Add MS 6783
f. 7 , but $ (fg + bd) $ there has been replaced by $ cd $ here.
Harriot's method, following Euclid, is to construct the square shown in the second diagram, in which the area of squares 1 + 3 represents $ \sqrt{cd} $ and the area of rectangles 2 + 2 represent $ fg $ (so each is of area $ \sqrt{\frac{fg}{4}} $. The side of square 1 is denoted by $ a $.
It is clear from simple geometry that area 1 : area 2 = area 2 : area 3, so Harriot can write down three proportional terms $ a $, $ \sqrt{\frac{fg}{4}} $, $ \sqrt{cd} - a $. Thus $ \frac{fg}{4} = \sqrt{cdaa} - aa $, leading to a quadratic equation in $ a $.
Harriot solves this equation by completing the square, giving him two possible values for $ a $. The side of the whole square is $ \sqrt{a} + \sqrt{\sqrt{cd} - a} $. Using either of his values for $ a $, he obtains the expression seen next to the words ‘Ergo Radix'. Squaring this expression gives him, as required, $ \sqrt{cd} + \sqrt{fg} $, the area of the whole square. He also observes that the sum of the roots gives him $ \sqrt{cd} $.

A binome is a quantity of the form $ \sqrt{m} + \sqrt{n} $.
On this page Harriot applies the method shown on Add MS 6783
f. 9 to find the square root of $ \sqrt{\frac{bc}{2} + \frac{dc}{2}} + \sqrt{\frac{bc}{2} - \frac{dc}{2}} $. The term 'universal' here signifies that he is taking the root of the entire quantity.

This folio refers to page 44v of Michael Stifel's Arithmetica integra
(Stifel 1544) . The relevant passage from Stifel is as follows.

quote.s:
De inventione numerorum, qui peculiariter pertinent ad suas species extractionum.
Restat iam ut tradam modum inueniendi numeros, qui peculiariter pertinent ad quam libet speciem extractionum, quatenus perfecta habeatur & absoluta huius negotij consumatio. Tradam autem huius modi inuentionem, per tabulam sequentem, quae ut in infinitum extendatur cuipse facile uidebis, quam primum uideris rationem qua construitur. Sic autem constructam uides.
On finding numbers which pertain particularly to the extraction of roots.
It remains for me to teach how to find numbers, which pertain particularly to extracting any root, that this matter might be perfected and wholly completed. Moreover, I teach this method of finding numbers by the following table, which may be extended indefinitely as you can easily see, once you have seen how it is constructed. Thus moreover you see it constructed.

p.s:
Stifel goes on to explain that the numbers in the second and subsequent columns are obtained as the sum of two entries from the preceding row.
Harriot's table is identical to Stifel's except that he has extended the rows further to the right.

This sheet refers to Stevin's L'arithmétique ... aussi l'algebre
(Stevin 1585a) . Pages 269 to 280 contain a section entitled 'De la reduction' on reducing, or simplifying, equations. On page 271, Stevin gives the first rule of reduction:

quote.s:
Reigle I.
Si les deux termes egaux donnez n'eussent pas l'inferieure quantité (0), on posera qu'il le soit, delaissant son signe de plus haulte quantité, & chascune des autres quantitez, descendra par egale distance.
Rule I.
If the two given equal sides do not contain the lowest quantity (of degree 0), one makes it so, lowering the degree of the highest quantity, and each of the other quantities will be lowered by the same amount.

p.s: On page 272, Stevin gives his second and third rules of reduction:

quote.s:
Reigle II.
Pour reduire le nombre de multitude de la superieure quantité en vnité, on divisera par lui toutes les quantitez proposées.
Reigle III.
Si les deux terms egaux eussent quantitez de mesme hauteur, on les ostera toutes deux, ou l'vne, par le moien d'egale addition, ou d'egale soubstraction.
Rule II.
To reduce the number of the highest quantity to one, one divides by that all the proposed quantities.
Rule III.
If the two equal sides have quantities of the same degree, one can get rid of both, or one of them, by means of equal addition or equal subtraction.

p.s: For each rule Stevin offered examples. Harriot re-worked all of them in his own notation.
Stevin. pa.271.

The table at the top right shows the numbers of Pascal's triangle set out in their simplest form.
The table at the top left shows the same numbers written as fractions, thus $ \frac{456}{123} $ on the diagonal is to be read as $ \frac{4 \times 5 \times 6}{1 \times 2 \times 3} = 20 $, and similarly for all the rest.
The third table displays the same numbers in a different arrangement, and suggests how they arise in the study of combinations.
Thus the first margin note is $ \frac{n}{n} $, that is, the number of ways of choosing $ n $ objects from $ n $. This is always 1, which appears repeatedly along the lowest diagonal.
The second margin note is $ \frac{n}{1} $, the number of ways of choosing 1 object from $ n $. The fractions $ \frac{n}{1} $ are seen along the second diagonal.
The third margin note is $ \frac{n(n - 1)}{1 \times 2} $, the number of ways of choosing 2 objects from $ n $. The fractions $ \frac{n(n - 1)}{1 \times 2} $ are seen along the third diagonal.
The fourth margin note is $ \frac{n(n - 1)(n - 2)}{1 \times 2 \times 3} $, the number of ways of choosing 3 objects from $ n $. The fractions $ \frac{n(n - 1)(n - 2)}{1 \times 2 \times 3} $ are seen along the fourth diagonal.
These rules were known to Harriot from his study of Girolamo Cardano, Opus novum de proportionibus
(Cardano 1570) , propositions 137 and 170 (see Add MS 6782
f. 44 ).
The fourth table displays the numbers in the same layout as the third table, but now explicitly calculated. The numbers 1, 2, 4, 8, 16, ... below it are the sums for each column. A note on the right observes that the sum for each column is twice that of the preceding one.

In the beginning God created the heaven and the earth

Quoniam $ da > aa $ ex data æquatione,
erit: $ d > a $ videlicet radice qualibet.
Because $ da > aa $ in the given equaion, evidently $ d > a $ for any root.

ergo si $ d = 370 $
erit: $ 370 > $ qualibet radix.
Therefore if $ d = 370 $, it must be that $ 370 > $ any root.

ergo qualibet radix in data æquatione numerorum
non constabit ex pluribus figuris quam tribus.
Therefore any root of the given equation in numbers cannot consist of more figures than three.

Nota.
Operatio pro eductione lateris maioris aliquando secundum partem
est similis operatione pro eductione lateris minoris. nimirum si
utraque latera consentiant in primis figuris. ut si
latus minus sit 23. maius 24. Ita si minus 343. maius 347.
et sic de cæteris.
Note.
The operation for extracting the greater root is sometimes similar in the second part to the extraction of the smaller; clearly if both roots agree in the first figures, as when the smaller root is 23, the greater 24. Thus if the smaller is 343, the greater 347, and so on for others.

Sed si differentiant in prima figura; dissimilis erit tota
operatio erant operationes totaliter, ut in exemplis
sit minor $ b $. maior $ c $.
antecedentibus in his chartis.
But if they differ in the first figure, the operations are totally different, as in the preceding examples in these sheets.

Against two of the equations on this page there are references to Stevin. These equations, $ 40 = - 6a + aaa $ and $ 20 = + 6a + aaa $ were treated by Stevin in L'arithmétique ... aussi l'algebre
(Stevin 1585a)
in his discussion of cubic equation without a square term (Problem LXIX). These equations were Stevin's first and second cases, treated at length on pages 305 to 311 and 311 to 314 respectively. Although Stevin gave the roots of each equation in the cube root form that Harriot gives here, he did not reduce them to their real equivalents. Thus, even though he observed that 4 is a root of the first equation, he did not explicitly identify $ \sqrt[3]{20 + \sqrt{392}} + \sqrt[3]{20 - \sqrt{392}} $ with 4.
Harriot's work is continued on the next few sheets, Add MS 6783
f. 73 ,
f. 73 ,
f. 73 . See also Add MS 6786
f. 401 , where he calculates $ \sqrt[3]{20 + \sqrt{392}} + \sqrt[3]{20 - \sqrt{392}} $ arithmetically.

quote.s:
Theorema 56, Propositio 58.
In omni triangulo sphærico, cuius duo arcus sint inæquales; quadratum sinus totius ad rectangulum sub sinubus rectis duorum arcuum inæqulium contentum, eandem proportionem habet, quam sinus versus anguli a dictis arcubus comprehensi ad differentiam duorum sinuum versorum, quorum vnus differentiæ eorundem arcuum debetur, alter vero tertio arcui, qui prædicto angulo oppostitus est, respondet.

In all spherical triangles, whose two arcs are unequal, the square of the whole sine to the product of the sines of the two unequal arcs is in the same ratio as the versed sine of the angle between the said arcs to the difference of two versed sines, one of which is of the difference of the arcs, the other corresponding to the third arc, which is opposite the aforesaid angle.

This page is the first of a 29-page section on cubic equations.
For a note on the tranlsation of 'genera', 'species', 'differentia', see Add MS 6783
f. 99 .
The upper left part of this page shows all possible combinations of positive and negative terms in linear, quadratic, cubic, quartic, and quintic equations.
The upper right half of the page contains a more sophisticated table, where the possibility of null terms is also taken into account. The box containing the figure 4, for instance, tallies the cases of cubic equation, excluding cases where all terms are negative. Thus, there is just 1 case of cubic equation with only a cube term; there are 3 cases with a cube and linear term; there are 3 cases with a cube and square term; and there are 7 cases with a cube, square, and linear term. These cases are listed explicitly on the following page, Add MS 6783
f. 99 .
The table in the lower half of the page collects and summarizes this information. Thus the total number of cubics, under the heading (3), is $ 1 \times 1 + 2 \times 3 + 1 \times 7 = 14 $.
Harriot also notes the totals, if cases where all the terms are negative are also counted.
For some drafts and rough versions of this page, see Add MS 6783
f. 406v ,
f. 409v ,
f. 404 .

On this page, Harriot begins to list all possible cases of linear, quadratic, cubic, and quartic equations. The list is completed on the following page, Add MS 6783
f. 100 .
From the way he has set out the list, we may translate his categories as follows: genera = degrees; species = types, according to the number of terms; differentia = individual cases.
The enumerations of these categories for equations of each degree are given in the table on the upper right in Add MS 6783
f. 99 .

On this page Harriot proves the two identities
$ a^3 + 3arq = r^3 - q^3 when $ a = r - q $,
$ a^3 - 3arq = r^3 + q^3 when $ a = r + q $.
These give him immediate solutions for equations that take these particular forms.

Here Harriot investigates the equation $ 2ccc = aaa + 3bba $. From the identity proved on the previous page, Add MS 6783
f. 101 , he knows that a solution is $ q - r $, where $ qr = bb $ and $ qqq - rrr = 2ccc $. Solving these last two equations simultaneously, he obtains two values of $ q $ (or $ r $), one of which is positive, the other negative.

Here Harriot investigates the equation $ 2ccc = - 3bba + aaa $. From the identity proved on Add MS 6783
f. 101 , he knows that a solution is $ q + r $, where $ qr = bb $ and $ qqq + rrr = 2ccc $. Solving these last two equations simultaneously, he obtains values of $ q $ and $ r $, leading to the standard solution formula for this type of equation.

Hic obiter notandum, quod:
$ bb,bb,bb $ apte enuntiatur, plani solidum. vel quadrati cubus
non autem cubo-cubus.
Here it is to be noted in passing that $ bb,bb,bb $ is rightly represented by a solid formed from planes, or the cube of squares, but not the cube of a cube.

Ita: $ ccc,ccc $ enunciandum, solidi planum vel cubi planum quadratum

Thus $ ccc,ccc $ must be represented as a plane formed from solids, or a square formed from cubes, but not the cube of a cube.

Blank page

Here Harriot examines three possible cases of the equation $ 2ccc = - 3bba + aaa $, when $ c > b $, $ c \lt b $, $ c = b $. He calls these hyperbolic, elliptic, and parabolic, respectively. (For a page where Harriot experimented with other names for these forms, see Add MS 6784
f. 416 .)
When $ c > b $, the equation has just one real root, given by the solution formula that Harriot has derived in sheets e.4, e.6, e.7, e.7.2 (Add MS 6783
f. 101 ,
f. 103 ,
f. 104 ,
f. 105 ). When $ c = b $, the equation has the double root $ a = - b $ and the single root $ a = 2b $. When $ c \lt b $, the equation has three distinct real roots, one positive and two negative; this is the 'impossible' case where the solution formula appears to give imaginary roots. However, Harriot has already shown in sheet d.4 (Add MS 6783
f. 180 ) that such equations have a real positive root.
Now Harriot wishes to show that, conversely, the canonical forms derived in d.4 and e.4 do in fact have the defining properties of hyperbolic, elliptic, or parabolic equations. To do this, he makes use of two simple lemmas proved on the back of this page (add MS 6783, f. 106v).
The canonical equation derived in e.4 was $ aaa - 3qra = rrr + qqq $. To show that this equation is hyperbolic, Harriot needs to prove that $ (\frac{qqq + rrr}{2})^2 > (qr)^3 $; this he is able to do using his two lemmas.
The elliptic and parabolic cases are proved in sheet e.9, that is, Add MS 6783
f. 107 .

Sheet e.4 is Add MS 6783

e duabus extremis maior est bis media.

extremis, maior est summa e duabus medijs.

erit æqualitas.

f. 101 ) is hyperbolic.

Lemma 1m
Lemma 1.

The canonical equation derived in d.4 (Add MS 6783
f. 180 ) was $ aaa - qqa - qra - rra = qqr + qrr $. To show that this equation is elliptic, Harriot needs to prove that $ (\frac{qqr + qrr}{2})^2 \lt (\frac{qq + qr + rr}{3})^3 $, which he is able to do. When $ r = q $, we have equality, giving the parabolic case of the equation.
Thus Harriot has proved what he set out to demonstrate, as stated on the previous page, e.8 (Add MS 6783
f. 106 ).

Tum 2o dico quod:

Et ita est per lemmata. Est igitur.

erit æqualitas.

Up to now, Harriot has attempted to solve the equation $ 2ccc = - 3bba + aaa $ using the canonical form derived on e.4 (Add MS 6783, 101). Now he tries using an alternative form, derived on d.4 (Add MS 6783
f. 180 ). He must therefore set $ qq + qr + rr = 3bb $ and $ qqr + qrr = 2ccc $. Unfortunately, attempting to solve these simultaneously only brings him back to the original equation, except that the sign of the unknown quantity is now reversed; Harriot calls this the conjugate equation (see Add MS 6783
f. 180 ). He then tries using a second canonical form derived in d.4, but again is forced back to the original equation. He concludes from this that the elliptic case can only be solved by means of its conjugate, or else by the 'general way', that is, by Viète's numerical method.

div.head:

On the solution of equations by reduction

resolvenda.

It is clear, therefore, that an elliptic equation, namely the seocnd case, cannot be solved by canons other than its conjugate, or in the general way.

Quæ suo loco in antecedentibus

Hoc tamen notandum, quod si
Eliptica soluatur per suam coniugatam: summa e duabus

However, this must be noted, that if an elliptic equation can be solved by its conjugate, the sum of the two roots of the conjugate will be the sought root of the elliptic equation.

Here Harriot solves the parabolic case of $ 2ccc = - 3bba + aaa $, the special case where $ b = c $. It is obvious that the only positive solution is $ a = 2b $.

On the solution of equations by reduction

Canon.
Canon

In this third case, suppose $ c = b $.

Whence the form of the equation will be as the canonical form.

forma Hyperbolica
hyperbolic form

Et aliter: sed non opus est.
And otherwise; but there is no need.

Hactenus de tribus casibus
æquationis adventitiæ:
Up to now we have dealt wtih three cases of the equation in question.
Blank page

Here Harriot turns to equations of the form $ 2ccc = + 3bba - aaa $. These are the 'avulsed equations' treated numerically in
Section c . Such equations may have either two positive roots or none. Harriot begins with a canonical form derived in sheet d.3 (Add MS 6783
f. 181 ) for an equaion with two positive roots. He must therefore set $ qq + qr + rr = 3bb $ and $ qqr + qrr = 2ccc $. However, this simply brings him back to the origina equaton. He therefore tries another canon, from d.4 (Add MS 6783
f. 180 ), which requires him to set $ qq - qr + rr = 3bb $ and $ qqr - qrr = 2ccc $. This brings him back to the conjugate of the original equation. He therefore concludes, as on sheet e.10 (Add MS 6783
f. 108 ) that the given equation can only be solved by means of its conjugate, or else by Viète's numerical method.

Quærendum quid $ = q = a $.
quid $ = r = a $.
From the equation in question there must be sought $ q $, or $ a $, and $ r $, or $ a $.

First, $ r $ is sought.

ut adventitia.
Either equation is the same as that in question.

Whence it appears that the equation in question must have two roots, as does the canon, that is

Otherwise, by another canon from d.4.

Quærendum ex adventitia quid $ = q - r = a $.
quid $ = r = a $.
From the equation in question there must be sought $ q - r $, which is $ a $, or $ r $, which is $ a $.

&c. ut (e.10.)

Here Harriot shows how the roots $ q $ and $ r $ of an equation of the form $ ggh = dfa - aaa $ can be determined from the known root $ q + r = x $ of the conjugate equation $ aaa - dfa = ggh $. To do this, he uses the first canonical form found on d.4 (Add MS 6783
f. 180 ).

As on sheet e.13 (Add MS 6783
f. 111 ) Harriot shows how the roots $ q $ and $ r $ of an equation of the form $ ggh = dfa - aaa $ can be determined from a known root $ x $ of the conjugate equation $ aaa - dfa = ggh $.
His second method uses the second canonical form from d.4 (Add MS 6783
f. 180 ).
His third method uses straightforward algebraic manipulation to arrive at the same result.
At the end of the sheet is a summary of what has been treated so far in Section e: the three equations $ ggh = + dfa + aaa $, $ ggh = - dfa + aaa $, and $ ggh = + dfa - aaa $, but not linear or quadratic equations, which Harriot regards as already sufficently well understood. In the remainder of this section, he will show how to reduce any other cubic equation to one of these three types, by removing the square term. This is the 'reduction' that appears in the title throughout this section.

This is the first page of a 7-page section on removing the cube term from a quartic equation; this is the 'reduction' that appears in the headings throughout Section f. Harriot's friend and colleague Nathaniel Torporley later denoted this subsection by the letter α, see:
(Stedall 2003) , 247–258, and
(section α) ). It is not self-contained, since the pagination (here 1 to 7) later continues into section γ (8 to 19), see:
(section γ) ), but it is convenient to treat these first seven pages together. There is also another version of it, for which Torporley used the letter β, see:
(section β) .
This first page shows the removal of the cube term from the quartic equations $ xxxz = \pm 4raaa + aaaa $, using the substitution $ a = \pm e \mp r $. Harriot then solves the resulting equation for $ e $, either by inspection or by the methods shown in subsection δ (see Add MS 6783
f. 137 ). This gives him the two real roots of the original equation. (The other two are imaginary.)

The first reference to Cardano is to his De arithmetica liber X, more commonly known as the Ars magna (1545). This was republished along with Cardano's De regula aliza, to which Harriot also refers (page 6), in the Opus novum de proportionibus
(Cardano 1570) .
The reference to Commandino is to his Euclidis elementorum XV
(Euclid 1572, 149, 149v) .

div.head: A note, for Mr Warner.

p.s:
Although Cardanus in the beginning of the first chapter pag. 6. of his 10th booke
of Arithmeticke would have $ \sqrt{9} $ to be $ + 3 4 or $ -3 $ yet in his Aliza
being a latter worke he was of an other opinion. I pray read his
32 chapter being at the 42 page. Ther you shall find him
iust of my opinion. The like also doth Comandino affirme in
his comment upon the 10th book of Euclide. see the 149 page & latter partes of the his
3 & 4 theoremes where he blameth those that minus not think
that minus per minus shall produce plus.
Blank page

For the continuation of this page, and diagrams, see Add MS 6783
f. 124 .
There are references to three propositions from Euclid's Elements: V.19, VI.14, and VI.17.

quote.s: V.19 If, as whole is to a whole, so is a part to a part subtracted to a part subtracted, the remainder will also be to the remainder as whole to whole.

VI.17 If three straight lines be proportional, the rectangle contained by the extremes is equal to the square on the mean: and, if the rectangle contained by the extremes be equal to the square on the mean, the three straight lines will be proportional.

p.s:
If there be three magnitudes proportionall of which the first is the greatest:
The square of the first, is æquall to the oblonge made of the difference
of the first & the second; & the whole line magnitude compounded of all these, together with
the oblonge made of the second & the last.

Let the three lines $ ab $, $ bc $, & $ cd $ represent the three magnitudes in continuall
proportion. From the poynt $ b $ & at right angles to the line $ ad $ let there be raysed
a perpendicular $ bg $ æquall to $ bc $. And $ gb $ draw out to $ h $ so that $ gh $ be æquall
to $ ab $. By the poynt $ h $ let the line $ ip $ be drawne parallell to $ ad $. And by the poynt $ g $
the line $ kq $ parallell also to $ ad $. Let $ iak $, $ hbg $, $ nco $, & $ pdq $, with $ xy $ & $ ut $ be also
parallelles. Then the figure $ ihgk $ is a square, & also $ bcog $. $ ia $ or $ hb $ is the
difference betweene $ ab $ & $ bg $ or $ bc $.

Now I say that the oblong $ id $ together with $ cq $ is æquall to the square $ ig $.
The oblong $ ho $, is æquall to the oblong $ ag $, because $ gh $ & $ gk $; $ hn $ & $ ak $ are
æquall.
Then is to be proved that $ nd $ is æquall to $ to $.

$ cd $ that is $ bt $ detracted from $ bc $ there remayneth $ tc $. & $ bc $ that is $ oc $ from
$ on $ which is all one with $ ab $, there remayneth $ cn $. Therefore by the 19th of the
5th, $ tc $ to $ cn $ is as $ dc $ to $ co $ & therefore alternately as $ tc $ to $ cd $
so $ nc $ to $ co $. Therefour (by the 17th of the 6th or the 14th of the same) the
oblongum $ nd $ is æquall to $ to $.

Then it is manifest that the oblong $ cq $ is æquall to $ bu $; & therefour
the oblong $ nq $ æquall to the square $ bo $ & therefore the figure $ hdo $
æquall to the figure $ ag $. Unto both put the figure $ ib $. Therefour
the square $ ig $. is æquall to the oblong $ id $ & $ do $; which was required
to be proved.

In like manner if there be four proportionalls, as let the fourth be $ de $
the square $ ig $ is æquall to the oblong $ ie $ & $ ds $. Make $ c\alpha $ æquall to $ de $
then as before $ \alpha d $ wilbe to $ de $ as $ pd $ to $ dq $ & therfour the oblong $ pe $ æquall
to $ \alpha q $, & the oblonge $ c\beta $ to $ ds $; Therefour is the before the oblongs $ id $ & $ do $
were æquall to the square $ ig $; now also the oblongs $ ie $ & $ eg $ which is æquall
to $ id $ & $ do $ must be also æquall. in like manner is the processe if
there were never so many proportionalls or infinite &c.
Hereby it followeth.

To give two infinite progressions, of which one to be
increasing & the other decreasing, that the totall summes
may be æquall.
although the nomber of places termes be infinite, the last
terms of both must be a quantity & finite.

To get the somme of an infinite progression is easy; but of a finite is to
to be done thus besides other wayes; but this way will prove in many many cases
when others will not, especially in bynomialles.

The finite progression understand to runne infinite & get the summe:
Then when the finite progression did do end, get 2 or 3 nombers more in
progression & from thence the get the summe of the infinite ; the difference
betwixt these summes of the two infinites is the summe of the finite progression.

As in Add MS 6783
f. 137
and
f. 138 , the equations on this page are solved by completing a square. Harriot does so by adding a quantity $ eeaa + \frac{eeee}{4} $ to each side of $ aaaa = \mp2ccda + xxxz $. The condition for the right-hand side to be a perfect square is that $ ee(\frac{eeee}{4} + xxxz) = (ccd)(ccd) $. This gives him a cubic equation for $ e $, which in principle can be solved by the methods demonstrated in Section e.
This is the standard method already taught by Cardano, Bombelli, Stevin, and Viète for solving quartic equations.

In a set of sheets lettered 'e' (Add MS 6783
(Section e) ) Harriot gave a comprehensive treatment of cubic equations. In a similar set of sheets lettered 'f' he did the same for quartic equations
(Section f) . Because there are many more cases of quartic to deal with, the sheets are more numerous, and are more widely dispersed amongst the mansucripts. After Harriot's death, his colleague Nathaniel Torporley allocated Greek letters to certain subsections of Section f, and we have followed that convention here. For further details of Torporley's notes on these pages, see
(Stedall 2003) , 17–26.
This is the first page of the 8-page section to which Torporley gave the letter δ
(section δ) ). The reason for putting this section first in the present scheme is that it treats quartic equations with no cube term, which can therefore be solved by 'completing the square'. The aim of all the other sections is to reduce more general quartic equations to this type so that they can be solved in the same way. This preserves an analogy with Harriot's treatment of cubics, where cubics with no square term were treated first, and all other case were then reduced to this special type.

On this page Harriot continues the explorations begun in Add MS 6783
f. 178 , of quadratic factors of the form $ df \pm aa $, but now in quartic equations. He is explicit here about the possibility of negative or imaginary roots.

div.head:
d.13.2o.) De generatione æquationum canonicarum.
On the generation of canonical equations

p.s: Blank page

On this page, for the first time in this section, Harriot solves a quartic equation not only for two real roots but also for two imaginary roots. He states that these are derived from the rules given on sheet e.13 (Add MS 6783, f.111). There, and on e.14 (Add MS 6783
f. 112 ) he showed how to derive two roots of an equation from a single known root of its conjugate. More specifically, given the single positive root $ x $ of an equation of the form $ aaa - dfa = ggh $, Harriot derived a quadratic equation for the two roots of the conjugate equation $ dfa - aaa = ggh $. That quadratic equation was $ ee - xe = df - xx $, with roots $ e = \frac{e}{2} \pm \sqrt{df - \frac{3xx}{4}} $.
On this page Harriot wants to solve the equation $ 20 = 11e - eee $. The conjugate equation is $ eee - 11e = 20 $, which has the single positive root $ e = 4 $ (as can be seen by inspection). Harriot therefore now has $ x = 4 $ and $ df = 11 $. Thus his quadratic equation is $ ee - 4e + 5 = 0 $, with roots $ e = 2 \pm \sqrt{-1} $. Previously he might have rejected these roots as 'impossible' (see sheet e.16, Add MS 6783, f. 197, but on this page he accepts them, and follows the working to its conclusion, giving him all four roots of the original equation.
He notes that roots of the kind he has found here are given by the canonical form $ (a - b)(a - c)(aa + df) $ shown in sheet d.13.2 (Ad MS 6783
f. 156 ), a sheet that has been inserted immediately before the present page.

Lemma. 1. Si duæ vel plures æquationes eiusdem vel diversuum
specierum habent communes radices: summa, vel differetia illorum
habebit easdem radices.
Lemma 1. If two or more equations of the same or different types have roots in common, their sum or difference will have the same roots.

Huisdmodo æquationes appello cognatas.

vel radices ut prima.

hoc est, sunt illi cognata.

The canonical equation derived on sheet d.5 (Add MS 6783

Similar calculations follow for the root $ f = \frac{bc + bd + cd}{b + c + d} $ on sheet c.8, that is, Add MS 6783

Another collection of canonical equations, as on Add MS 6783
f. 170
and
f. 169 , but now for equations with as many positive roots as the degree of the equation. The last of these, an equation of fifth degree, has not been derived in the pages of Section d but can be written down by analogy; see also Add MS 6784
f. 427 .
Viète, at the end of his De recognitione et emendatione æquationum, tractatus duo
(Viète 1615) , offered several collections of equations and their solutions. In general Harriot's collections are different from Viète's. This page, however, contains the same equations as Viète's fourth and final collection, the 'Collectio quarta'. I would argue that Viète derived his equations by his method of syncrisis (see
Stedall 2011, 24–27 ), which is quite different from Harriot's multiplication of factors.

On the two previous pages he demonstrated the conditions required for the terms in $ aa $ and $ aaa $, or $ a $ and $ aa $, to vanish simultaneously. Now he investigates the conditions for the third case, for both $ a $ and $ aaa $ to vanish, and finds the resulting form of the coefficients in terms of the two positive roots $ b $ and $ c $. On this page Harriot explores the multiplications $ (a - b)( a - c)(a - d)( a - f) = 0 $ and $ (a - b)( a - c)(a - d)( a + f) = 0 $.
In the latter case, he demonstrates the conditions required for the terms in $ aaa $, $ aa $, or $ a $ to vanish, and finds the resulting form of the coefficients in terms of the three positive roots $ b $, $ c $, and $ d $.
From this it is easy for him to see the close relationship between the equations in Add MS 6783

On this page Harriot explores the multiplication $ (a - b)( a - c)(a + d) = 0 $. He argues that $ b $ and $ c $ are the (positive) roots of this equation, and that any other root $ d $ can only be equal to either $ b $ or $ c $.
Equations with two positive roots are precisely the kind Harriot is interested in for the purposes of Section c. He therefore demonstrates the conditions required for the terms in $ aa $ or in $ a $ to vanish, and the form of the resulting coefficients in terms of $ b $ and $ c $.

In this 21-page section (Section d), Harriot develops one of his most original ideas in algebra: the generation of polynomial equations from the multiplication of linear and quadratic factors. All previous treatments of quadratic, cubic, or quartic equations had been based on traditional ideas of proportion. Harriot broke decisively away from such a model, completely changing the way equations were perceived and studied. This was the one section of Harriot's work that was published after his death, edited by his friend Walter Warner as the Artis analyticae praxis (1631). Warner, however, seems not to have fully understood all of Harriot's working, and the version given in the Praxis is very different from the systematic treatment seen in the manuscripts. Further, Warner eliminated all negative or imaginary roots, leading later readers to assume that Harriot never handled them. That he did so is clear from the later pages in this section.
The 'canoncial equations' in Section d are prototypes, generated from a given set of roots. Note that Harriot has already used these canonical equations in Section c (Add MS 6783
f. 417
to
f. 400 ); see, for example, Add MS 6783
f. 417 , f (for quadratics),
f. 415 ,
f. 414 ,
f. 411 ,
f. 410 ,
f. 409 ,
f. 408 (for cubics),
f. 407 ,
f. 406 ,
f. 404 ,
f. 403 ,
f. 402 ,
f. 400 (for quartics). These are different from some other equations, also described as 'canonical', also to be found in Section c. For a page that shows both types, see Add MS 6782
f. 408 . There the first canonical form is of the kind derived here in Section d, for a cubic equation with no linear term, and with two positive roots $ b $ and $ c $. The second canonical form is used for numerical solution; in that case, $ b $ and $ c $ represent the first and second digits of the root. Thus $ b $ and $ c $ have entirely different interpretations in the two forms; fortunately, their specific meanings in any calculation are always clear from the context.
The equations in Section c are all trinomial in form, with the highest power subtracted (torn away, or 'avulsed') from the second highest power. Such equations have either no positive roots or two of them. From his study of Viète's numerical method, Harriot was particularly interested in the latter case. His aim in Section d is to discover the conditions under which an equation with two positive roots reduces to trinomial form, and the nature of the resulting coefficients in terms of those two roots. Thus Sections c and d are very closely related, and there are several specific cross-references from one to the other. For further discussion see
Stedall 2011 .
As for other parts of Harriot's work on equations, algebraic manipulations and single words contained in them are not transcribed in this section.
In this first page (d.1) Harriot sets out the multiplications he intends to explore, in modern notation $ (a - b) $, $ (a - b )(a - c) $, $ (a - b)(a + b) $, $ (a - b)(a - c)(a - d) $, and so on.
After the trivial case $ a - b = 0 $, Harriot treats the multiplication $ (a - b)(a - c) = 0 $, arguing that $ b $ and $ c $ are both (positive) roots of this equation, but that there can be no other (positive) root $ d $, say.
He then treats the multiplication $ (a - b)(a + c) $ in a similar way, arguing that in this case $ a = b $ is the only (positive) root. At this stage he is still concerned only with positive roots, though this will change later.

This page begins with the sixth and last of the equations given by Viète in De numerosa potestum resolutione, in the section entitled 'De ambiguitate cubi multipliciter adfecti' ('On ambiguity in cubic equations with multiple terms'), following Problem 18
(Viète 1600b) .
Harriot then goes on to discuss some of the 'precepts' given by Viète, with his own corrections to them.
Viète's first equation was (in modern notation) $ x^3 - 6x^2 + 11x = 6 $. Harriot gives this in the form $ aaa - 6aa + 11a = 6 $. Viète claimed that this has three real and distinct roots (namely, 1, 2, and 3) because $ 3 \times \left(\frac{6}{3}\right)^2 > 11 $. In more general terms, for an equation $ x^3 - px^2 + qx - r = 0 $, this condition may be written $ 3\left(\frac{p}{3}\right)^2 > q $ (condition (i)). It is true that if all the roots are real, this condition will be satisfied. If the roots are $ b $, $ c $, $ d $, for instance, then it is equivalent to $ 3\left(\frac{b + c + d}{3}\right)^2 > bc + cd + db $, precisely the inequality Harriot proves on the next page, sheet e.28 (Add MS 6783
f. 185 ), Lemma 2. However, although this condition is necessary for the equation to have three real roots, it is not sufficient. To demonstrate this, Harriot adjoins a second example, $ aaa - 6aa + 11a = 12 $, where the condition is again satisfied, but the equation has only one real root, $ a = 4 $. Harriot claims that a further condition is necessary for three (real) roots, namely, $ \left(\frac{p}{3}\right)^3 > r $ (condition (ii)). This is equivalent to $ \left(\frac{b + c + d}{3}\right)^3 > bcd $, the inequality that he proves on sheet e.29 (Add MS 6783
f. 184 ), Lemma 3. Harriot's first equation satisfies condition (ii), but the second does not. However, as before, he has only shown that condition (ii) is necessary for three real roots, not that it is sufficient.
Viète made a further claim: that the roots of the first equation (namely, 1, 2, and 3) are equally spaced because $ 6 + 2 \times \left(\frac{6}{3}\right)^3 = 11 \times \frac{6}{3} $. In more general terms, using the notation above, $ r + 2\left(\frac{p}{3}\right)^3 = \frac{p}{3}q $. Viète did not justify this statement but it is not difficult to check that this condition must indeed hold if the roots are equally spaced.
Harriot next turns to examples when condition (i) becomes an equality, that is, $ 3\left(\frac{p}{3}\right)^2 = r $ (condition (i')). Viète claimed that this leads to three equal roots, as in the equation (in modern notation) $ x^3 - 6x^2 + 12x = 8 $, with roots 2, 2, 2. Harriot writes this in the form $ aaa - 6aa + 12a = 8 $. Harriot again shows that although Viète's condition is necessary for three real roots, it is not sufficient. He does so by adjoining a second example, $ aaa - 6aa + 11a = 9 $, where condition (i') is satisfied, but the equation has only one real root, $ a = 3 $. Harriot claims that a further condition is necessary for three (real) roots, namely (in the above notation), $ r + 2\left(\frac{p}{3}\right)^3 = \frac{p}{3}q $ (condition (ii')). This is precisely Viète's condition for equally spaced roots, but Harriot offers no justification for his statement.
His first equation satisfies condition (ii'), but his second does not.
Harriot's third condition, in the above notation $ 3\left(\frac{p}{3}\right)^2 \le q $, is the negation of condition (i); when this holds there can be only one real root, as in his example, $ aaa - 6aa + 13a = 8 $.
Harrot's fourth condition, in the above notation $ \left(\frac{p}{3}\right)^3 \le r $, is the negation of condition (ii); when this holds there can be only one real root, as in his two examples, $ aaa - 6aa + 11a = 12 $ and $ aaa - 6aa + 12a = 9 $.

a cubic equation affected by a negtive square and a positive side will have more than one root when three times the square of a third of the longitudinal coefficient is greater than the plane coefficient (and the cube of the same third is greater than the given solid) and is a cube with three sides.

The equations on this page are the first five of those discussed by Viète in De numerosa potestum resolutione, in a section entitled 'De ambiguitate cubi multipliciter adfecti' ('On ambiguity in cubic equations with multiple terms'), following Problem 18
(Viète 1600b) . The sixth and last equation appears on the following page, e.27 (Add MS 6783
f. 186 ).
Viète gave various conditions, all expressed verbally, and all offered without proof, for such equations to have distinct or equal roots and, in the case of distinct roots, for them to be equally or unequally spaced. Harriot discusses these conditions, which he calls 'precepts', on the following page, e.27 (Add MS 6783
f. 186 ).

Similarly, the square term of $ + 3raa - aaa = - 2xxx $ is removed by setting $ a = r - e $.
This leads to the conjugate of the equation obtained by the first method. However, under the constraints that $ r $ and $ x $ are positive, such an equation has no positive roots, as Harriot shows in his 'Demonstratio' on the right. At this stage, he therefore regards such an equation as 'impossible'. Later, in sheet f.14 (Add MS 6783

Harriot continues his exploration of the equation generated by the multiplication $ (a - b)( a - c )( a - d )( a + f ) = 0 $. Here he invesitgates the conditions required for two terms, in $ aa $ and $ aad $ to vanish simultaneously. This leads him to values of $ d $ and $ f $ which are clearly imaginary or, in the language of Harriot's time, 'impossible' (since $ b $ and $ c $ are both supposed positive). This is a contradiction since $ d $ was supposed positive. Harriot does not seem concerned about this, however, and goes on to add and multiply $ d $ and $ f $ without comment. When Warner came to edit these pages in the Artis analyticae praxis (1631), he was troubled by these manipulations and omitted them, stating that they were 'not clear'. The contradiction lingers in the fact that Harriot started from an equation with three positive roots, but ends up with an equation with only two, even though his procedures have done nothing to change the roots themselves.

This sheet refers to Stevin's L'arithmétique ... aussi l'algebre
(Stevin 1585a) . On page 308, Stevin wrote the following, about equations he described as 'imparfaicte' (imperfect). These are equations with three real roots, but where the solution formula appears at first sight to give imaginary roots.

quote.s:
Il auient en aucuns exemples de ceste difference, que le quarré de la moitie du (0) donné, sera moindre que le cube du tiers du nombre de multitude de (1) donnée; D'ou s'ensuit que le mesme cube, ne se pourra soubstraire d'iceluy quarré, comme veut la reigle de la precedent construction; de sorte que ceste premiere difference (ensemble aucuns exemples des problemes suiuans, que se conuertissent en icelle) est encore imparfaicte. Rafael Bombelle la solve par diction de plus de moins & moins de moins en ceste sorte:
It happens in some examples of this type, that the square of half of the given term will be less than the cube of a third of the number of the linear term. From which it follows that the same cube cannot be subtracted from that square, as required by the rule of the preceding construction; so that this first type (together with some examples in the following problems, which convert to it) is still imperfect. Rafael Bombelli solves it by speaking of more of less and less of less in this way.

p.s:
Stevin went on to give a solution of 1(3) = 30(1) + 36 (in modern notation $ x^3 = 30x + 36 $) involving $ \sqrt{-676} $. He also observed that 6 is a solution.
Harriot worked on the same equation, written as $ aaa - 30a = 36 $.

For the 1579 edition of Bombelli's L'algebra see
(Bombelli 1579)

This is the first of a set of 10 pages of notes on Viète's Effectionum geometricarum canonica recensio
(Viète 1593b, Props 5, 6) , which supplies 20 Euclidean constructions of lines in given arithmetical or proportional relationships. Propositions 1 and 2, for example, simply show how to add or subtract one line to or from another. Proposition 3 gives the standard Euclidean construction for three lines in geometric proportion, Proposition
VI.13 .
On this page, Harriot gives his own versions of Propositions 5 and 6.

quote.s:
Propositio V.
Datis duabus lineis rectis, invenire mediam inter eas proportionalem.
Given two straight lines, to find their mean proportional.

Propositio VI.
Datis duabus lineis rectis, invenire tertiam proportionalem.
Given two straight lines, to find a third proportional.

p.s: Harriot, following Viète, describes the first as the work of multiplication, and the second as the work of division. This can be seen more clearly from Harriot's algebraic treatment than from Viète's geometric construction. This, in Proposition 5, the square of $ d $ (the line to be constructed) represents the product of the given lines $ b $ and $ c $. In Proposition 6, the line $ c $ (to be constructed) represents the quotient $ \frac{dd}{b} $ of the given quantites $ dd $ and $ b $.

Opus multiplicationis.)

Let $ fd $ be the perpendicular, denoted $ d $.

Aliter
sit $ aa = bc $
et quæritur. $ a $
ergo: $ b , a : a , c $.
Igitur
Inter $ b $ et $ c $ inveniatur
media proportionalis,
et signetur $ d $.
Another way.
Let $ aa = bc $, and $ a $ is sought, that is, $ b : a = a : c $.
Therefore between $ b $ and $ c $ there may be found a mean proportional, denoted by $ d $.

Invenire, planum $ = dd $
cuius unum
latus datum, nempe, $ b $.
Opus applicationis.)
fiat $ bf = b $.
et $ df = d $. perpendicularis.
agatur $ bd $. et secetur bisariam in $ g $.
sit $ ga $, perpendicularis, quæ secabit $ bf $ lineam productam in $ a $.
centro $ a $. intervallo $ ab $, fiat periferia.
quæ secabit $ bf $ productam in $ c $ puncto.
notetur $ fc $ $ c $.
To find a plane equal to $ dd $, of which one side is given, namely $ b $ (the work of division).
Construct $ bf = b $, and $ df = d $, the perpendicular. Join $ bd $ and let it be bisected at $ g $. Let $ ga $ be a perpendicular, which cuts the line $ bf $ produced at $ a $. With centre $ a $ and radius $ ab $ construct the circumference, which cuts $ bf $ produced at the point $ c $.
It may be observed that $ fc $ is $ c $.

Aliter
sit $ be = dd $
et quæritur. $ e $
ergo: $ b , d : d , e $.

Another way.

On this page, Harriot works on Propositions 7 and 8 from Viète's Effectionum geometricarum canonica recensio
(Viète 1593b, Props 7, 8) .

quote.s:
Propositio VII.
Datis trianguli rectanguli duobus lateribus circa rectum, invenire latus tertium.
Given the two sides of a right-angled triangle around the right angle, to find the third side.

Propositio VIII.
Dato latere subtendere angulum rectum trianguli, & uno e reliquis, invenire latus rectum.
Given the side subtending the right angle of a triangle and one of the others, find the other side.

p.s: In the upper half of the page, Harriot proves that the triangle with sides $ b $, $ c $, $ d $ is right-angled. In the lower half of the page he gives a brief algebraic summary of Propositions VII and VIII. Following Viète, he describes the first as addition (of planes) and the second as subtraction (of planes).

div.head:
b.) Effectiones geometricæ
Geometrical constructions

On this page, Harriot works on Propositions 9 and 10 from Viète's Effectionum geometricarum canonica recensio
(Viète 1593b, Props 9, 10) .

quote.s:
Propositio IX.
Si fuerint tres lineæ rectæ proportionales: quadratum minoris extremae adjunctum rectangulo sub differentia extremarum & ipsa minore extrema, æquatur mediæ quadrato.
If there are three proportional straight lines, the square of the lesser extreme added to the product of the difference of the extremes and that lesser extreme, is equal to the square of the mean.

Propositio X.
Si fuerint tres lineæ rectæ proportionales: quadratum majoris extremae multatum rectangulo sub differentia extremarum & ipsa majore extrema, æquatur mediæ quadrato.

If there are three proportional straight lines, the square of the greater extreme reduced by the product of the difference of the extremes and that greater extreme, is equal to the square of the mean.

p.s: In both of these propositions, Viète showed how the standard construction for three proportionals can lead to the given equation. Harriot works the other way round: beginning from an equation, he gives a construction that represents the same relationship geometrically. This is what he means by 'effectio æquationis' or 'the construction of an equation'.

div.head:
d.) Effectiones geometricae
Geometric constructions

p.s:
Effectio æquationis
1.) $ ba + aa = dd $ vel: $ 2,ca + aa = dd $.
Construction of an equation
1.) $ ba + aa = dd $ or $ 2ca + aa = dd $.

fiat $ GF = b $
secetur $ GF $ bisariam in $ A $.
et signentur partes $ AG $. $ AF $. $ c $.
sit $ FD $ perpend: $ = d $
Agatur $ AD $.
centro, $ A $. intervallo $ AD $.
describatur periferia $ BDC $
quæ secabit $ GF $ productam
in punctes. $ B $. $ C $.
Dico quod $ FC = a $.
cui æqualis $ GB $.
Construct $ GF = b $, and let it be bisected at $ A $, and denote the parts $ AG $, $ AF $, by $ c $. Let the perpendicular $ FD $ be $ d $. Connect $ AD $. With centre $ A $ and radius $ AD $, describe the circumference $ BDC $, which will cut $ GF $ produced in the points $ B $ and $ C $.
I say that $ FC = a $, which is equal to $ GB $.

vel binis caracteribus.
or in double letters

Effectio æquationis
2.) $ aa - ba = dd $ vel: $ aa - 2ca = dd $.
Construction of an equation
2.) $ aa - ba = dd $ or $ aa - 2ca = dd $.

constructio ommnino ut supra
vel binis caracteribus.
The construction of everything is as above
or in double letters.
Blank page

On this page, Harriot works on Proposition 11 from Viète's Effectionum geometricarum canonica recensio
(Viète 1593b, Prop 11) .

quote.s:
Propositio XI.
Si fuerint tres lineæ rectæ proportionales: rectangulum sub composita ex extremis & harum altera majore minorve, multatum ejusdem alterius quadrato, æquatur mediae quadrato.
If there are three proportional straight lines, the product of the sum of the extremes and either the greater or the lesser, reduced by the square of the same, is equal to the square of the mean.

p.s:
In this proposition, as in propositions IX and X, Viète showed how the standard construction for three proportionals can lead to the given equation. As on the previous page (Add MS 6783
f. 236 ), Harriot works the other way round: beginning from the equation, he gives a construction that represents the same relationship geometrically. He notes that the construction gives both the positive roots that are to be expected for this case.

fiat $ BC = b $
secetur $ BC $ bisariam in $ A $.
et signentur partes $ AB $. $ AC $. $ c $.
centro, $ A $. intervallo $ AB $.
describatur circulas periferia
sit $ AG $ perpendicularis $ BC $
fiat $ AI = d $.
sit $ ID $ parallela $ AC $.
et $ DF $ parallela $ IA $.
Ergo. $ DF = IA = d $.
Dico quod $ a $ erit duplex, $ BF $ vel $ FC $.
Construct $ BC = b $, and let $ BC $ be bisected at $ A $, and denote the parts $ AB $, $ AC $, by $ c $. With centre $ A $ and radius $ AB $, describe a circumference. Let $ AG $ be perpendicula to $ BC $. Construct $ AI = d $. Let $ ID $ be parallel to $ AC $ and $ DF $ be parallel to $ IA $. Therefore $ DF = IA = d $.
I say that $ a $ will be twofold, $ BF $ or $ FC $.

This sheet contains some of Harriot's rough work on problems from Stevin's L'arithmetique pratique
(Stevin 1585b) . Pages 44 to 47 contain the 'Quatriesme Distinction' of Part II, on the Rule Alligation. The working on this page relates to Examples II and III on page 46:

quote.s:
Exemple II.
Quelcun à deux sortes de blez, la premiere de 2 ß le boisseau, la seconde de 7 ß le boisseau, & en veut faire 8 boisseaux chacun de 6 ß. Combien prendra il de chacune sorte?
Exemple III.
Vn maistre de monnoie à cinq sortes d'or, la premier de 2 Karatz, la seconde de 3 Karatz, la troisieme de 4, la quatriesme de 11, la cinquiesme de 12; Et veut faire vne masse de 20 marcqs à 5 Karatz; Combien se prendra de l'or de chascune sorte?
Example II.
Someone has two sorts of wheat, the first at 2 ß a bushel, the second at 7 ß a bushel, and wants 8 bushels at 6 ß. How much must he take of each sort?
Example III.
A money handler has five sorts of gold, the first of 2 carats, the second of 3 carats, the third of 4, the fourth of 11, the fifth of 12; and wants to make a weight of 20 marks at 5 carats; How much gold must he take of each sort?

p.s:
Stevin.
pag. 46.
pratique

div.head: Of alligation

p.s:
This sheet contains some of Harriot's work on problems from Stevin's L'arithmetique pratique
(Stevin 1585b) . Pages 47 to 121 contain the 'Cinquiesme Distinction' of Part II, on the Rule of Interest. Page 64 contains a table headed 'Table d'interest simple dommageable, de 12 pour 100'. Harriot confirms the first figure in the table, 8928571, by dividing 1000000000 by 112. The page also contains other calculations on interest.

Exemple V
Ily a vn quadrangle rectangle ABCD, duquel la superfice faict 14, & le costé AB est double au costé AD, la demande est de combien soit chascun desdicts costez.
Example V
There is a rectangle ABCD, of which the surface is 14, and the side AB is double the side AD; the question is how long is each of the said sides.

On this page, Harriot finds the root of a sixth binome ($ \sqrt{fg + bd} + \sqrt{fg} $) by the method shown on Add MS 6783
f. 9 , and uses his result to find the square roots of $ \sqrt{24} + \sqrt{8} $ and $ \sqrt{20} + \sqrt{12} $. The first of these is what Harriot sometimes refers to as bin. $ 6' $, since $ 24 - 8 = 16 $, a square. The second is what he sometimes refers to as bin. $ 6'' $, since $ 20 - 12 = 8 $, a non-square. In the first case, he notes that the root is a sum of a binome and an apotome of the fifth kind; in the second case, the root is a sum of a binome and an apotome of the sixth kind.
For further results of this kind see Add MS 6783
f. 362v .

The second is what he sometimes refers to as bin. $ 5'' $, since $ 12 - 2^2 = 8 $, a non-square (it is impossible to see whether he does so here because the edge of the page is lost in the binding). In the first case, he notes that the root is a sum of a binome and an apotome of the fifth kind; in the second case, the root is a sum of a binome and an apotome of the sixth kind.

f. 356v ).

On this page, Harriot derives general formulae for binomes of the fifth sixth kind.
The upper half of the page, below the number '5.)', contains several versions of a formula for fifth binomes, the simplest of which, marked 'melius' (best), is $ \sqrt{bb + cd} + b $. Note, however, the special case $ \sqrt{bb + cc} + \sqrt{bb} $, where the difference between the square of the two terms is itself a square. Elsewhere, Harriot denotes this special kind ($ \sqrt{bb + cc} + \sqrt{bb} $) as bin. $ 5' $ and the more general kind ($ \sqrt{bb + cd} + \sqrt{bb} $) as bin. $ 5'' $.
The lower half of the page, below the number '6.)', contains several versions of a formula for sixth binomes, the simplest and most general of which is $ \sqrt{fg + cd} + \sqrt{fg} $. Note, however, as for fifth binomes, the special case $ \sqrt{fg + cc} + \sqrt{fg} $, where the difference between the square of the two terms is itself a square. Elsewhere, Harriot denotes this special kind ($ \sqrt{fg + cc} + \sqrt{fg} $) as bin. $ 6' $ and the more general kind ($ \sqrt{fg + cd} + \sqrt{fg} $) as bin. $ 6'' $.

Rough work

This is the first of a set of 14 numbered pages on binomes. The six types of binome are defined in Euclid's Elements in
Book X; Definitions II , in the following way.

quote.s:
1. Given a rational straight line and a binomial, divided into its terms, such that the square on the greater term is greater than the square on the lesser by the square on a straight line commensurable in length with the greater, then, if the greater term is commensurable in length with the rational straight line set out, let the whole be called a first binomial straight line.
2. But if the lesser term is commensurable in length with the rational straight line set out, let the whole be called a second binomial.
3. And if neither of the terms is commensurable in length with the rational straight line set out, let the whole be called a third binomial.
4. Again, if the square on the greater term is greater than the square on the lesser by the square on a straight line incommensurable in length with the greater, then, if the greater term is commensurable in length with the rational straight line set out, let the whole be called a fourth binomial.
5. If the lesser, a fifth binomial.
6. And if neither, a sixth binomial.

p.s:
These definitions may be written in modern notation as follows.
Binome 1: a binome of the form $ m + \sqrt{n} $ with $ m > \sqrt{n} $, and $ m^2 = n + k $ where $ \frac{m}{\sqrt{k}} $ is rational; for example $ 7 + \sqrt{48} $.
Binome 2: a binome of the form $ \sqrt{m} + n $ with $ \sqrt{m} > n $, and $ m = n^2 + k $ where $ \frac{\sqrt{m}}{\sqrt{k}} $ is rational; for example $ \sqrt{12} + 3 $.
Binome 3: a binome of the form$ \sqrt{m} + \sqrt{n} $ with $ \sqrt{m} > \sqrt{n} $, and $ m = n + k $ where $ \frac{\sqrt{m}}{\sqrt{k}} $ is rational; for example $ \sqrt{8} + \sqrt{6} $.
Binome 4: a binome of the form $ m + \sqrt{n} $ with $ m > \sqrt{n} $, and $ m^2 = n + k $ where $ \frac{m}{\sqrt{k}} $ is non-rational; for example $ 2 + \sqrt{2} $.
Binome 5: a binome of the form $ \sqrt{m} + n $ with $ \sqrt{m} > n $, and $ m = n^2 + k $ where $ \frac{\sqrt{m}}{\sqrt{k}} $ is non-rational; for example $ \sqrt{2} + 1 $.
Binome 6: a binome of the form $ \sqrt{m} + \sqrt{n} $ with $ \sqrt{m} > \sqrt{n} $, and $ m = n + k $ where $ \frac{\sqrt{m}}{\sqrt{k}} $ is non-rational; for example $ \sqrt{3} + \sqrt{2} $.
Harriot made two further distinctions for binomes of the fifth and sixth kind according to whether $ k $ is itself a square (type i) or not (type ii).
Harriot also investigated two further kinds of irrational quantities defined by Euclid: first and second bimedials. These are defined in Euclid X.37 and X.38.

quote.s:
X.37 If two medial straight lines commensurable in quare only and containing a rational rectangle be added together, the whole is irrational; and let it be called a first bimedial straight line.
X.38 If two medial straight lines commensurable in quare only and containing a medial rectangle be added together, the whole is irrational; and let it be called a second bimedial straight line.

Rough work on square roots of binomes

A table of square roots of binomes. Down the left hand side of the table Harriot has listed eight kinds of binomes of the first kind, that is, of the form $ a + \sqrt{b} $ where $ a^2 > b $. They are distinguished by the fact that their square roots are binomes of the first, second, third, fourth, fifth, or sixth kind. Note that Harriot defines two classes of binome of the fifth kind and of the sixth kind. In each case, those in the first class are those special cases where the difference between the square of the two terms is itself a square. Harriot observes that 'Euclides non distinxit', that is, that Euclid does not make this distinction.
The third column shows the square roots of the square roots, that is, the fourth roots of the original quantity.
The fourth and final column gives the names assigned by Euclid to these fourth roots.
At the bottom of the page are some further quantities 'omitted by Euclid'.

The first section demonstrates that the square root of a third binome is the root of a third binome plus the root of a third apotome.
The third section gives the square root of a fourth binome.
The fourth section demonstrates that the square root of a fifth binome of the second kind is the root of a sixth binome of the first kind plus the root of a sixth apotome of the first kind.
The fifth section demonstrates that the square root of a fifth binome of the first kind is the root of a fifth binome of the first kind plus the root a fifth apotome of the first kind.
The sixth section demonstrates that the square root of a sixth binome of the first kind is the root of a fifth binome of the second kind plus the root a fifth apotome of the second kind, and that the square root of a sixth binome of the second kind is the root of a sixth binome of the second kind plus the root a sixth apotome of the second kind.
The seventh section demonstrates again that the square root of a sixth binome of the first kind is the root of a fifth binome of the second kind plus the root a fifth apotome of the second kind, and that the square root of a sixth binome of the second kind is the root of a sixth binome of the second kind plus the root a sixth apotome of the second kind.
For Harriot's two kinds of fifth and sixth binomes, see Add MS 6784, 216.

The rule for the square root of a binome of the sixth kind ($ \sqrt{4bc} + \sqrt{4bc - 4df} $), checked by multiplication. A rule for the sixth binome is easily adapted to all other binomes, which can be regarded as particular cases of it.

Blank page

This folio provides a canon, or rule, for finding the cube root of a quantity $ d + f $.
Using the fundamental property established in the first line, the first denominator of the canon can be rewritten as the cube root of
$ 2bbb + 6bcc + 3((b + c)(bb - cc) + (b - c)(bb - cc)) $
$ = 2bbb + 6bcc + 6b(bb - cc) $
$ = 8bbb $.
Similarly, the second denominator yields $ 8ccc $. Thus taking cube roots and dividing by 2 yields $ b + c $, as required.
A numerical example is worked at the bottom of the page.

On this folio Harriot explains how to find the cube root of a quantity of the form $ \sqrt{fff} + \sqrt{ggg} $, where $ fff $ and $ ggg $ take the particular form shown, so that their difference is the cube of $ b - c = d $. Harriot derives a cubic equation for $ c $, enabling him to find $ \sqrt{b} $ and $ \sqrt{c} $.
